<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mutex:
```c
static int mutex(void)
{
	metal_mutex_t lock;
	const int threads = 10;
	int rc;

	metal_mutex_init(&lock);

	rc = metal_run(threads, mutex_thread, &lock);

	metal_mutex_deinit(&lock);

	return rc;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function mutex:
int metal_run(int threads, metal_thread_t child, void *arg)
{
	pthread_t tids[threads];
	int error, ts_created;

	error = metal_run_noblock(threads, child, arg, tids, &ts_created);

	metal_finish_threads(ts_created, (void *)tids);

	return error;
}
...
int metal_run_noblock(int threads, metal_thread_t child,
		     void *arg, void *tids, int *threads_out)
{
	int error, i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}

	error = 0;
	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++) {
		error = -pthread_create(&tid_p[i], NULL, child, arg);
		if (error) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to create thread - %s\n",
				  strerror(error));
			break;
		}
	}

	*threads_out = i;
	return error;
}
...
void metal_finish_threads(int threads, void *tids)
{
	int i;
	pthread_t *tid_p = (pthread_t *)tids;

	if (!tids) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid argument, tids is NULL.\n");
		return;
	}

	for (i = 0; i < threads; i++)
		(void)pthread_join(tid_p[i], NULL);
}
...
static void *mutex_thread(void *arg)
{
	metal_mutex_t *l = arg;
	int i;

	for (i = 0; i < mutex_test_count; i++) {
		metal_mutex_acquire(l);
		usleep(1);
		metal_mutex_release(l);
	}

	return NULL;
}
...
typedef struct {
	atomic_int v;
} metal_mutex_t

Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c

		error = -pthread_create(&tid_p[i], NULL, child, arg);
		if (error) {

```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No. The fragment calls strerror(error) but does not pass any pointer parameter from <string.h> that could be indexed out of bounds. The string functions in the fragment are limited to strerror (which takes an int, not a pointer) and the returned pointer is used read-only in the log. This does not cause accesses beyond the bounds of objects referenced by pointer parameters as required by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. (Note: there is an unrelated risk that error is set to a negative value via error = -pthread_create(...); passing a negative/invalid errnum to strerror is a semantic bug and you may prefer strerror_r or ensure a valid positive errno, but that is not a 21.17 pointer-bounds violation.)
